caseinfo:casename.caseinfo:fullcasename: The People of the State of New York, Respondent, v. Timothy Bleakley and Jeffrey J. Anesi, Appellants

jurisinfo:courtinfo.jurisinfo:courtname: Court of Appeals of New York

p.text: Appeals, by permission of an Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals, from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department, entered December 31, 1986, which affirmed two judgments (one as to each defendant) of the Westchester County Court (Joseph K. West, J.), rendered upon a verdict convicting each defendant of two counts of rape in the first degree, one count of sodomy in the first degree and one count of sexual abuse in the first degree.

Defendants appealed from the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed their convictions of two counts of rape in the first degree, one count of sodomy in the first degree, and sexual abuse in the first degree.

An intermediate appellate court committed reversible error when it manifestly avoided its exclusive statutory authority to determine whether the jury verdicts convicting defendants of sexual offenses were supported by the weight of the evidence.

Defendants were convicted by a jury of two counts of rape in the first degree, one count of sodomy in the first degree, and sexual abuse in the first degree. Their convictions were affirmed by the appellate court. On further appeal, the court reversed their convictions, concluding that the appellate court had failed to determine whether the jury verdict was supported by the weight of the evidence. The appellate court's analysis should not have been limited to a determination that the verdict was supported by sufficient evidence. If, based on all the credible evidence, a different finding would not have been unreasonable, then the appellate court was required to weigh the relative probative force of conflicting testimony and the relative strength of conflicting inferences that could be drawn from the testimony. The case was remanded for the appellate court to engage in that review.
The appellate court's judgment was reversed because it failed to determine if the jury verdict was supported by the weight of the evidence, which was the required analysis for its review.

text.emph: Crimes -- Appeal -- Intermediate Appellate Courts -- Reversible Error for Intermediate Appellate Court to Manifestly Avoid Exclusive Statutory Authority to Review Weight of Evidence

p.text: 1. It is reversible error when the Appellate Division manifestly avoids its exclusive statutory authority to review the weight of the evidence in criminal cases. Accordingly, where the Appellate Division concluded on an appeal from two judgments convicting defendants of rape in the first degree, sodomy in the first degree and sexual abuse in the first degree, that the jury verdict was supported by sufficient evidence, but did not do the factual analysis of whether the jury determination was against the weight of the evidence, a review which may take place only in an intermediate appellate court ( CPL 470.15 [5]), the Appellate Division's order of affirmance is reversed and the case is remitted to the Appellate Division to complete its consideration of the case, including application of its weight of evidence review.

text.emph: Crimes -- Appeal -- Intermediate Appellate Courts -- Standards of Review -- Legal Sufficiency -- Weight of Evidence

p.text: 2. Although the two standards of intermediate appellate review in criminal cases -- legal sufficiency and weight of evidence -- are related -- each requires a discrete analysis. To conclude that a jury verdict is supported by sufficient evidence, the intermediate appellate court must determine whether there is any valid line of reasoning and permissible inferences which could lead a rational person to the conclusion reached by the jury on the basis of the evidence at trial and as a matter of law satisfy the proof and burden requirements for every element of the crime charged. If that is satisfied, then the verdict will be upheld by the intermediate appellate court on that review basis. To determine whether a verdict is supported by the weight of the evidence, however, the intermediate appellate court's dispositive analysis is not limited to that legal test. If based on all the credible evidence a different finding would not have been unreasonable, then the intermediate appellate court must, like the trier of fact below, weigh the relative probative force of conflicting testimony and the relative strength of conflicting inferences that may be drawn from the testimony. If it appears that the trier of fact has failed to give the evidence the weight it should be accorded, then the intermediate appellate court may set aside the verdict ( CPL 470.20 [2]).

courtcase:representation.courtcase:counsel: Oren Root, Jr., and Patrick M. Wall for appellants. I. Because Agosta's testimony was severely inconsistent and untrustworthy, Bleakley and Anesi were not proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt as a matter of law. ( People v Reed, 40 NY2d 204; People v Santos, 38 NY2d 173; People v Ledwon, 153 NY 10; People v Stewart, 40 NY2d 692; People v Hughes, 41 AD2d 333, 36 NY2d 981; People v Gay, 63 AD2d 590; People v Foster, 64 NY2d 1144; People v Wells, 48 AD2d 934; People v Johnson, 90 AD2d 777.) II. Despite being requested to, the court below failed to exercise either its factual or interest-of-justice jurisdiction in evaluating the prosecution's proof at trial. ( Jackson v Virginia, 443 U.S. 307; People v Pollenz, 67 NY2d 264; People v Smith, 63 NY2d 41; People v Taylor, 138 NY 398; People v Crum, 272 NY 348; People v Rickert, 58 NY2d 122; People v Yanik, 43 NY2d 97; People v Cignarale, 110 NY 23.) III. The prosecutor committed reversible error in her summation by vouching and by accusing defendants of "rehearsing" their "story" and of making allegations they did not make. ( People v Galloway, 54 NY2d 396; People v Steinhardt, 9 NY2d 267; People v Vera, 94 AD2d 728; People v Manson, 63 AD2d 686; People v Morales, 53 AD2d 517; People v Wright, 41 NY2d 172; People v Ashwal, 39 NY2d 105; People v Puglisi, 44 NY2d 748.) IV. The introduction of evidence that Bleakely had another criminal case pending when arrested for this matter gravely prejudiced both defendants. ( People v Malkin, 250 NY 185; Krulewitch v United States, 336 U.S. 440; People v Harris, 52 AD2d 560; People v Lyles, 63 AD2d 740; People v Watson, 55 AD2d 873.) V. A statement made by Anesi in police custody was unconstitutionally elicited. ( People v Skinner, 52 NY2d 24; Edwards v Arizona, 451 U.S. 477; People v Ferro, 63 NY2d 316; People v Maerling, 46 NY2d 289; People v Velasquez, 68 NY2d 533; People v Lanahan, 55 NY2d 711; People v Townes, 41 NY2d 97; People v Lucas, 53 NY2d 678; People v Crimmins, 36 NY2d 230.)

Carl A. Vergari, District Attorney (Richard L. Hecht and Anthony J. Servino of counsel), for respondent. I. Appellants' guilt for the crimes of rape in the first degree (two counts each), sodomy in the first degree and sexual abuse in the first degree was proven by legally sufficient evidence beyond all reasonable doubt. The claim that the intermediate appellate court refused to consider the weight of the evidence or misapplied the "standard of review" attendant thereto is both outside this court's scope of review and without basis in law or fact. ( People v Malizia, 62 NY2d 755, 469 U.S. 932; People v Gruttola, 43 NY2d 116; People v Contes, 60 NY2d 620; People v Fuller, 50 NY2d 628; People v Shedrick, 66 NY2d 1015; People v Goodfriend, 64 NY2d 695.) II. Appellants' contention that they were prejudiced by the People's summation is unpreserved for appellate review and without basis in law. ( People v Arce, 42 NY2d 179; People v De Jesus, 42 NY2d 519; People v Dordal, 55 NY2d 954; People v Young, 48 NY2d 995; People v Ayala, 120 AD2d 600, 68 NY2d 755; People v Marks, 6 NY2d 67, 362 U.S. 912; People v Gilmore, 106 AD2d 399; People v Galloway, 54 NY2d 396.) III. The inadvertent mentioning of a pending charge, promptly and directly cured, did not prejudice Bleakley, who voluntarily placed a previous arrest before the jury. Anesi's derivative claim is unpreserved for review. ( People v Nuccie, 57 NY2d 818; People v Love, 57 NY2d 1023; People v Garcia, 72 AD2d 356, 52 NY2d 716.) IV. The trial court correctly ruled that Anesi's statement was spontaneously made and, thus, admissible at trial. Bleakley's derivative claim is unpreserved for review. ( People v Hoke, 62 NY2d 1022; People v Lynes, 49 NY2d 286; People v Rivers, 56 NY2d 476; People v Lanahan, 55 NY2d 711; People v Harris, 57 NY2d 335.)

courtcase:panel.courtcase:judges: Bellacosa, J. Chief Judge Wachtler and Judges Simons, Kaye, Alexander, Titone and Hancock, Jr., concur.

p.text:
We hold that Appeals, Reversible ErrorHN1
It is reversible error when an intermediate appellate court manifestly avoids its exclusive statutory authority to review the weight of the evidence in criminal cases.it is reversible error when the Appellate Division manifestly avoids its exclusive statutory authority to review the weight of the evidence in criminal cases.

Each defendant, Timothy Bleakley and Jeffrey J. Anesi, has been found guilty by a jury at a joint trial of two counts of rape in the first degree, one count of sodomy in the first degree and sexual abuse in the first degree. By a divided court, the Appellate Division affirmed the judgments of conviction.

The principal issue is whether defendants have been deprived of one of their available statutory standards of intermediate appellate court review, a review based on the weight of the evidence ( CPL 470.15 [5]). We discern that in this case they have been so deprived.

The very serious crimes for which both defendants stand convicted started out with some drinking in taverns late in the evening, then some social and amicable bar encounters in the early morning hours which evolved to an automobile setting where the victim and the two defendants planned to "do some coke" together. They did so. The versions of what happened thereafter differ sharply. The victim testified to a horrible and forcible double rape and sodomy. The defendants testified to one consensual sexual incident. There is other evidence of a circumstantial nature dealing with sexual conduct and possible forcible circumstances. There are also serious credibility and discrepancy assertions with respect to all the key witnesses.

text.rfc:reasonforciting:
Unquestionably, these features all relate principally to the jury's properly exercised function and its resolution in this respect eliminates any further relevant concern with respect to the evidentiary standard of sufficiency or reasonable doubt (this is not a People v Ledwon, 153 NY2d 10, or People v Santos, 38 NY2d 173, type case). But, based on what is before us on this record, Standards of Review, Substantial EvidenceEvidence, Weight & SufficiencyHN2
An intermediate appellate court must do the factual analysis of whether the jury determination is against the weight of the evidence, a review which may take place only in an intermediate appellate court. N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 470.15(5).the Appellate Division did not do the factual analysis of whether the jury determination was against the weight of the evidence, a review which may take place only in an intermediate appellate court ( CPL 470.15 [5]).

p.text: The complementary review scheme erected in our Constitution and statutes imposes a heavy duty on our important and overburdened intermediate appellate courts which speak the final word in most cases and especially with respect to review of fact issues. That is why the issue is so critical to the proper outcome of this case.

text.rfc:reasonforciting:
Unlike this court which, with few exceptions, passes on only questions of law, Standards of Review, Questions of Fact & LawAppeals, ReviewabilityHN3
Intermediate appellate courts are empowered to review questions of law and questions of fact. They do so in both civil cases under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 5501(c) and criminal cases under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 470.15.intermediate appellate courts are empowered to review questions of law and questions of fact. They do so in both civil cases ( CPLR 5501 [c]) and criminal cases ( People v Redmond, 225 NY 206; People v Stevens, 104 NY 667; CPL 470.15). Indeed, this unique factual review power is the linchpin of our constitutional and statutory design intended to afford each litigant at least one appellate review of the facts (Cohen and Karger, Powers of the New York Court of Appeals § 109, at 465 [rev ed]).

On the criminal side, however, the history of this unique review power had been the subject of some confusion. For years an appellate determination that the verdict was against the weight of the evidence warranted only the ordering of a new trial, while sufficiency and reasonable doubt deficiencies necessitated the corrective action of dismissal of the criminal charges (see, e.g., People v McCaleb, 25 NY2d 394; People v Klose, 18 NY2d 141; People v Bellows, 281 NY 67; compare, People v Holmes, 52 NY2d 976; People v Robare, 109 AD2d 923). The Criminal Procedure Law revisors recommended and the Legislature enacted a significant clarifying change upgrading the corrective action to dismissal of criminal charges under either standard of review (see, CPL 470.20 [2], [5]; People v Crimmins, 36 NY2d 230; People v Kidd, 76 AD2d 665). The change was justified because, in the words of the drafters, "[the] People, having had full opportunity to prove their case at trial and having failed to do so, should not be accorded another chance" (Staff Comment to Proposed CPL 240.40, at 328 [1967]).

rfc:reasonforciting.rfc:reasonforciting: This case presents a new difficulty. The Appellate Division (125 AD2d 687 [2d Dept], lv granted 69 NY2d 744) was divided as to whether its review power was limited to a determination of the legal sufficiency of the evidence or whether it should also weigh the evidence and, if appropriate, reverse the judgments based on a factual determination that the verdict was against the weight of the evidence. In upholding the judgments of conviction, a majority of the court articulated the view that their function as an appellate court was not to substitute their judgment for that of the jury on matters of credibility or the weight to be accorded to the evidence presented at trial, but rather to determine whether, after viewing the evidence in a light most favorable to the prosecution, any rational trier of fact could have found that the defendants' guilt had been proven beyond a reasonable doubt ( id., at 691). Indeed, the majority took exception to the dissent's conclusion that the guilty verdicts were contrary to the weight of the evidence.

text.rfc:reasonforciting: "[By] voting to reverse the judgments of conviction based on apparent inconsistencies in the complainant's testimony, our dissenting colleague chooses to ignore the well-established legal standards with respect to the scope of appellate review in criminal cases" ( id., at 692; see also, cases cited in the respective opinions).

Standards of Review, Substantial EvidenceEvidence, Weight & SufficiencyHN4
Although the two standards of intermediate appellate review, legal sufficiency and weight of evidence, are related, each requires a discrete analysis. For a court to conclude that a jury verdict is supported by sufficient evidence, the court must determine whether there is any valid line of reasoning and permissible inferences which could lead a rational person to the conclusion reached by the jury on the basis of the evidence at trial and as a matter of law satisfy the proof and burden requirements for every element of the crime charged. If that is satisfied, then the verdict will be upheld by the intermediate appellate court on that review basis.Although the two standards of intermediate appellate review -- legal sufficiency and weight of evidence -- are related, each requires a discrete analysis. For a court to conclude, as the Appellate Division did in this case, that a jury verdict is supported by sufficient evidence, the court must determine whether there is any valid line of reasoning and permissible inferences which could lead a rational person to the conclusion reached by the jury on the basis of the evidence at trial ( Cohen v Hallmark Cards, 45 NY2d 493, 499) and as a matter of law satisfy the proof and burden requirements for every element of the crime charged. If that is satisfied, then the verdict will be upheld by the intermediate appellate court on that review basis.

Standards of Review, Substantial EvidenceEvidence, Weight & SufficiencyHN5
To determine whether a verdict is supported by the weight of the evidence, the appellate court's dispositive analysis is not limited to that legal test of sufficiency of the evidence. Even if all the elements and necessary findings are supported by some credible evidence, the court must examine the evidence further. If based on all the credible evidence a different finding would not have been unreasonable, then the appellate court must, like the trier of fact below, weigh the relative probative force of conflicting testimony and the relative strength of conflicting inferences that may be drawn from the testimony. If it appears that the trier of fact has failed to give the evidence the weight it should be accorded, then the appellate court may set aside the verdict. N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 470.20(2).To determine whether a verdict is supported by the weight of the evidence, however, the appellate court's dispositive analysis is not limited to that legal test. Even if all the elements and necessary findings are supported by some credible evidence, the court must examine the evidence further. If based on all the credible evidence a different finding would not have been unreasonable, then the appellate court must, like the trier of fact below, "weigh the relative probative force of conflicting testimony and the relative strength of conflicting inferences that may be drawn from the testimony" ( People ex rel. MacCracken v Miller, 291 NY 55, 62; compare, People v Smith, 63 NY2d 41, 52; see also, Cohen and Karger, Powers of the New York Court of Appeals § 112, at 484 [rev ed]). If it appears that the trier of fact has failed to give the evidence the weight it should be accorded, then the appellate court may set aside the verdict ( CPL 470.20 [2]).

p.text:
Empowered with this unique factual review, Standards of Review, Substantial EvidenceHN6
Intermediate appellate courts are careful not to substitute themselves for the jury. Great deference is accorded to the fact-finder's opportunity to view the witnesses, hear the testimony, and observe demeanor.intermediate appellate courts have been careful not to substitute themselves for the jury. Great deference is accorded to the fact-finder's opportunity to view the witnesses, hear the testimony and observe demeanor. Without question the differences between what the jury does and what the appellate court does in weighing evidence are delicately nuanced, but differences there are.

Here the Appellate Division, on a plain reading of the majority and dissenting opinions, failed to provide its exclusive review authority which is expressly withheld from the trial court and even from this court. We must, therefore, remit for that court to complete its consideration of the case, including application of its weight of evidence review.

In directing the corrective action in this case, we do not imply that the Appellate Division must manifest its weight of evidence review power by writing in all criminal cases (compare, CPL 470.25 and 470.40). But where the order and writings of the intermediate appellate court manifest a lack of application of that review power which appellants are entitled to, then we reverse and remit.
We have examined the other issues and conclude they are not dispositive or meritorious.
Accordingly, the order of the Appellate Division should be reversed and the case remitted for further proceedings in accordance with this opinion.
